The main problem with this product is that it is overpriced and completely unnecessary. Lip exfoliation is one of the simplest, most inexpensive beauty routines one can engage in at home because it only requires two basic ingredients that virtually every household has on hand: sugar and oil. Specifically, all that is required to exfoliate the lips is a tiny amount of granular sugar, either white table sugar (sucrose as in this product), brown sugar, raw sugar, or sugar alcohol such as xylitol. Add to that an equal amount of any food-grade oil you have on hand in the house, for example: olive oil, canola oil, safflower oil, or coconut oil. One-fourth teaspoon each of granular sugar and oil is enough to do both lips. The instructions for do-it-yourself exfoliation are as follows: In a small bowl or saucer, measure out one-fourth teaspoon of granular sugar. On top of it put an equal amount of oil. Wash your hands and dry them thoroughly. Blend the sugar and oil together with the tip of your finger. Rub the sugar-oil mixture onto your lips in a circular motion for two-five minutes. Gently scrub off the mixture with a clean, damp washcloth to remove not only the sugar and oil, but any loosened, dead skin. If flaking, dead skin still remains on your lips, rub more of the sugar-oil mixture onto your lips and repeat the above process. After you are finished, immediately moisturize your lips, ideally with a natural, food-grade oil or a lip balm made with an oil-beeswax mixture, since anything that goes on the lips ultimately ends up in the mouth and stomach. The second problem with this product is that even though the container looks small, there is enough of this product to last a very long time. And while it is sitting on your bathroom shelf, it is slowly drying out. Within six months to a year, long before you've used more than a fraction of it, this product will deteriorate into a hard, unusable lump (not to mention that most cosmetics companies recommend throwing out their products anyway within six to nine months because of inevitable bacteria buildup). If you make your own sugar-oil mixture each time you need it, nothing is wasted, and it is always fresh, with a smooth, viscous consistency that glides onto your lips. The third problem with this product is that, though some of the ingredients are natural and food-grade, others are not. The ingredients for this product include: "Sucrose, Petrolatum, Flavor, Caramel, Simmondsia Chinensis (Jojoba) Seed Oil, VitiVinifera (Grape) Seed Oil." Below is a description of each ingredient. The most problematic one is petrolatum. It is too bad that the makers of this product didn't just stick to grapeseed oil, which is a natural, healthy oil. Sucrose is simple white/table sugar. Petrolatum: This lab-derived substance has been around since 1859 when chemist Robert Chesebrough developed a method of purifying a black gel that clogged oil rigs called "rod wax." This is a very thick substance which is anything but ideal for exfoliating the skin. Flavor: It is not specified whether this is "artificial" or "natural" flavor. Artificial flavor is derived from non-food substances, that is, chemicals created in a lab. Natural flavor is derived from a real food, but the process by which it is derived is unexplained. In both cases, there is no way to know how safe or healthy the flavoring is. Caramel: This is sugar or syrup heated until it turns brown. It can either be used as a coloring agent or to impart flavor. Jojoba oil is a natural plant oil. It is created from the liquid wax of the seed of the jojoba plant, a shrub which is native to southern Arizona, southern California, and northwestern Mexico. It's much healthier than petrolatum, but it contains 14% erucic acid, which is not recommended to be taken internally. Grapeseed oil is a natural oil derived from the seeds of grape. It contains vitamin E and antioxidants.

You'd probably need 6 total to do your entire body the recommended number of times (I believe it's first four treatments 2 weeks apart, next three treatments 3-4 weeks apart, and then treatments as needed and only in specific areas, but it is all in the book you get with the kit), and then another 1-2 for any extra maintenance or trouble areas that may be causing trouble, so that gives you a better idea of pricing overall.

Day 1 - January 4: "All I know is I got shot by a laser. Gosh darnit, my *censored* hurts. You're right about it being like a rubber band." -Boyfriend wanted to use it, too. He shot my legs, underarms, and bikini area. It actually melted any stubble so I believe it was working the right way. Make sure you shave the day before. He used the 5 the whole time on me, per my request, as I read a lot of reviews that said it only works at that level. It really did feel like a rubber band. Basically the softer tissue was when it hurt. I hardly felt it on my legs or stomach, mostly just my inner thighs. I also felt it around my knees while they were bent, but when I stretched out it was fine (book says don't laser skin that's not tight, so this is apparently why). We are thinking about the white eyeliner tip for round 2, as one of the issues was it was very hard to keep track of where we were. Thus far, it didn't seem to cause any irritation. Best part: the sound effects. Pew pew!

Day 2 - January 20: Thus far, I've noticed I definitely had to shave in between.  My hair was still growing, and it was still coming in with no noticeable difference - to me.  However, not to be discouraged, we tried again!  Online articles said to expect only 10% of hair gone for any sort of laser hair removal.  During the process, my boyfriend used the singed bits of stubble as a sort of guide, and he also pressed down a bit harder as he went to leave a minor impression and keep track of where he had been.  We did my legs (only the inside of my thighs and then all of my lower legs) and under my arms, and then he also shot a few areas on his body.  He said that not a lot of hair has grown back from the areas he did.  One spot was a mole, but I did still notice a couple hairs.  He did one of my underarms twice on accident, so we'll compare the two and see if this is a positive strategy - that's for next time!  Keep you posted. (Also, the light is quite bright.  I hid my head under a blanket both this time and last, and my boyfriend was wearing sun glasses.  One of the other reviewers said they bought special glasses.  I don't think it's necessary for such a small procedure, but if you're doing multiple people or for some reason will need way more treatments or if you're actually doing your entire body, then at least wear sun glasses but please consider special glasses.  Come on, it's your eyes.)

Day 3 - January 26: I don't really see a difference, but it's only the third treatment now. It may be my imagination, but some of the hair seemed thinner.  The instructions say to go every two weeks for the first few treatments, but my hair was starting to grow back and I had to shave Friday for the weekend, so we decided to have at it.  Hopefully my last $10 razor purchase!  My boyfriend said there was a noticeable difference between my two underarms, so I suppose it was a happy accident that we did one twice.  It meant a lot more overlap where the laser hit, which is where I think the real benefit was.  Because of this, he did both of my underarms twice today.  However, please note I DO NOT recommend doing this as it did leave minor burn marks after the second time, and the second time also hurt and felt burning - but come on, if you're zapping your skin on highest intensity TWICE then you better expect it!  However, it really just looks reddish, and it's just under my arms so no one sees it anyway.  A little lotion or aloe and it will be fine.  Also, I could smell the burning hair.  I definitely would NOT do my legs that way! We made it through one lower leg and then had to switch the laser cartridge to the second one. (Two per initial box.)  So, that means that one cartridge made it down both my legs twice (plus one more leg) and under my arms twice, and then did my bikini line twice and a couple spots on my boyfriend twice.  I have some BAD NEWS, though.  The little laser got really hot - which is part of the reason it burned me a bit more today and hurt more than it had before - and then it stopped working.  We were not misusing it, so I believe it was just a defective unit.  It's not a big deal since Amazon's return policy is solid.  I am going to send it back for a refund rather than a replacement because I don't know if it is really working or not.  However, if it is actually working, I will buy a new one and get back on it!  I'm going to give it two weeks and then reevaluate the status of my hair.  It sounds silly but I took a picture of my underarm today so I can actually compare.

Final update: After a series of three photos (the final a month after returning the device), I realized there was little to no hair loss.  What grew back is "softer," which implies the hair is thinner, but I will not be purchasing a new device at this time.  I am considering other alternatives.

It actually works somehow!  We tested it by peeling an orange by hand, and even rubbing our hands in the Orange peels before washing. We did a before and after "sniff" test.  To use it, pretend it is a bar of soap, and rub it between your hands and fingers for 30-40 seconds under running water. After 30 seconds, we could still smell some orange, but we ran it for another ten seconds, and the odor was gone!  Only the slightest hint of orange lingered on our hands. The stainless steel "soap bar" smelled the way it did when it was first taken out of the box.  I am not sure how this works, but it does. There was no residue or any indication that the "bar" had been treated with anything, or that it released any liquid, etc.  It appears to just be a blob of stainless steel shaped to look like a bar of soap, but it works at taking away odors from hands!
